title: Water Quality, nutrients and the European Union’s Water Framework Directive in a lowland agricultural region:  Suffolk, south-east England.
abstract:
The water quality of 13 rivers in the lowland, agricultural county of Suffolk is investigated using routine monitoring data for the period 1981 to 2006 collected by the Environment Agency of England and Wales (EA), and its predecessors, with particular emphasis on phosphorus (as total reactive phosphorus, TRP) and total (dissolved and particulate) oxidised nitrogen (TOxN – predominantly nitrate NO3). Major ion and flow data are used to outline fundamental hydrochemical characteristics related to the groundwater provenance of base-flow waters.  Relative load contributions from point and diffuse sources are approximated using Load Apportionment Modelling for both TRP and TOxN where concurrent flow and concentration data are available.  Analyses indicate a mixture of point and diffuse sources of TRP, with the former being dominant during low flow periods, while for TOxN diffuse sources dominate.\ud
Out of 59 sites considered, 53 (90%) were found to have annual average TRP concentrations greater than 0.05 mg P l-1, and 36 (61%) had average concentrations over 0.120 mg P l-1, the upper thresholds for ‘High’ and ‘Good’ ecological status, respectively.  Correspondingly, for TOxN, most of the rivers are already within 70% of the 11.3 mg N l-1 threshold, with two rivers (Wang and Ore) being consistently greater than this.\ud
It is suggested that the major challenge is to characterise and control point-source TRP inputs which, being predominant during the late spring and summer low-flow period, coincide with the peak of primary biological production, thus presenting the major challenge to achieving ‘good’ ecological status under the Water Framework Directive.  Results show that considerable effort is still required to ensure appropriate management and develop tools for decision-support.\u

Water Quality, nutrients and the European Union’s Water Framework Directive in a lowland 
agricultural region:  Suffolk, south-east England. 
Nicholas J K Howden1*, Michael J Bowes2, Neil Humphries1,3 and Colin Neal2 
1National Soil Resources Institute, Natural Resources Department, School of Applied Sciences, Cranfield 
University, Cranfield, Bedfordshire, MK43 0AL; 
2Centre for Ecology and Hydrology, Wallingford, Oxfordshire, OX10 9BB; 
3URS Corporation Ltd, The Derwent Business Centre, Clarke Street, Derby, DE1 2BU. 
 
Abstract 
The water quality of 13 rivers in the lowland, agricultural county of Suffolk is investigated using routine 
monitoring data for the period 1981 to 2006 collected by the Environment Agency of England and Wales 
(EA), and its predecessors, with particular emphasis on phosphorus (as total reactive phosphorus, TRP) 
and total (dissolved and particulate) oxidised nitrogen (TOxN – predominantly nitrate NO3). Major ion 
and flow data are used to outline fundamental hydrochemical characteristics related to the groundwater 
provenance of base-flow waters.  Relative load contributions from point and diffuse sources are 
approximated using Load Apportionment Modelling for both TRP and TOxN where concurrent flow and 
concentration data are available.  Analyses indicate a mixture of point and diffuse sources of TRP, with 
the former being dominant during low flow periods, while for TOxN diffuse sources dominate. 
Out of 59 sites considered, 53 (90%) were found to have annual average TRP concentrations greater than 
0.05 mg P l-1, and 36 (61%) had average concentrations over 0.120 mg P l-1, the upper thresholds for 
‘High’ and ‘Good’ ecological status, respectively.  Correspondingly, for TOxN, most of the rivers are 
already within 70% of the 11.3 mg N l-1 threshold, with two rivers (Wang and Ore) being consistently 
greater than this. 
It is suggested that the major challenge is to characterise and control point-source TRP inputs which, 
being predominant during the late spring and summer low-flow period, coincide with the peak of primary 
biological production, thus presenting the major challenge to achieving ‘good’ ecological status under the 
Water Framework Directive.  Results show that considerable effort is still required to ensure appropriate 
management and develop tools for decision-support.

Introduction 
Here, the water quality of the rivers draining to the eastern part of Suffolk are examined.  Information is 
drawn from the extensive Environment Agency (EA) database to characterise long-term patterns in water 
quality and to examine spatial coverage and long-term patterns of change for Total Oxidised Nitrogen 
(TOxN) and total reactive phosphorus (TRP) across the region.  This study area has a relatively low 
human population density (176 people per km2 compared with 379 and 430 people per km2 for England 
and SE England respectively (Office of National Statistics, 2008)), and this study will provide an 
important contrast to previous studies of highly urbanised catchments that are typical of southern Britain. 
There are five strategic reasons for this study. (1) It is this type of region with high agricultural coverage 
where the UK debate on farming, regional economics and the aquatic environment is critical. (2) 
Intensive agricultural areas in this part of the UK have received little attention. (3) The Water Framework 
Directive (WFD) requires a basin-wide integrated approach and the study of these coastal Suffolk rivers 
provides a representative example and at an appropriate scale to consider this approach. (4)  There are 
requirements for ongoing monitoring to support both understanding of catchment function and 
management of water quality; the utility of existing data must be assessed in order to inform and target 
future monitoring requirements. (5) The coastal context of these rivers makes their catchment areas of 
ecological significance in respect of freshwater, inter-tidal and coastal habitat provision of national and 
international significance (Howden et al., 2006). 
 
Background 
In recent decades there has been a major research effort to determine nutrient concentrations and fluxes 
from agricultural areas and their impact on surface waters (Neal and Heathwaite, 2005), largely due to the 
European Community Water Framework Directive (WFD: EA, 2002) which is designed to foster 
improving the ecology and amenity value of UK surface waters (e.g. Hilton et al., 2006).  For the UK, 
phosphorus (P) rather than nitrogen (N) is generally considered to be the limiting nutrient in rivers

(Mainstone and Parr, 2002;  Withers and Lord, 2002) and much attention is focussed on the lowlands, 
where nutrient inputs are greatest due to high population densities and intensive/extensive agriculture.  A 
central water quality issue is the impact of nitrogen (nitrate) and phosphorus (phosphate) on 
eutrophication (EA, 2000, Withers and Lord, 2002, Mainstone and Parr, 2002 and DEFRA, 2004), both of 
which derive primarily from sewage and agricultural sources.  Knowledge of the relative contributions of 
nutrients from these sources is vital for effective river catchment management (Withers and Sharpley, 
2008). 
In addressing nutrient sources, the WFD requires the control of both point and diffuse inputs into water 
bodies, which might well prove costly; in the case of farming, large changes may be required to lower 
nutrient concentrations below ecologically significant thresholds.  As point sources of pollution are 
increasingly controlled, non-point or diffuse sources of pollution become relatively more important. 
However, given the complexity of agricultural landscapes, managing the risk of diffuse pollution is not 
straightforward (Burt and Pinay, 2005), because diffuse pollution varies considerably as a complex 
function of soil type, climate, topography, hydrology, land use and management (Heathwaite et al., 2005).  
This can create widespread, intermittent and poorly defined contaminant sources that degrade water 
quality in a way that makes their control difficult.  Most research on diffuse pollution has involved 
surface and near-surface flow paths, but in catchments with high groundwater baseflow contributions, 
there is an added complexity because of the long pathways and residence times involved in nutrient 
transfer through the aquifer (Mathias et al., 2007). Major sources of inorganic P, are often associated with 
high population density and sewage treatment work (STW) discharges and even in agricultural areas, 
inputs from habitation and local STWs cannot generally be ignored (Muscutt and Withers, 1996; Neal et 
al., 1998c, 2004b, 2006a, 2008a,b; Bowes et al., 2005a; Neal and Jarvie, 2005;  Jarvie et al., 2006a). 
Thus, catchments that are defined in terms of “rural” or “agricultural” are a misnomer: such catchments 
are a mix of rural farming, rural settlement and in some cases peri-urban components (Neal et al., 2006a). 
Hence the system needs to be considered in a more “holistic” way that in some respects is much fairer to 
the farming community in terms of pollutant sources and impacts.

For NO3, agriculture is considered the predominant source (Johnes and Burt, 1993; Neal et al., 2006b), 
but leaching from farmland is linked to many factors such as fertilisation, soil texture, land use, 
disturbance, crop rotation and effluent disposal (Vinten and Smith, 1993). 
For environmental management purposes it is essential to assess the levels of their inputs and provide 
focussed measures for amelioration strategies (Neal and Jarvie, 2005); and in the lowlands where 
agriculture often provides the dominant inputs of nitrate, and there are clear measures in place for 
remediation such as the introduction of nitrate vulnerable zones (DoE, 1993; Jordan and Smith, 2005). 
For phosphate, there is often a more balanced mix of fluxes from agricultural and various effluent sources 
across many parts of the British lowlands (Mainstone and Parr, 2002; Smith et al., 2005a;  Wood et al., 
2005).  Point effluent sources are of particular importance in terms of eutrophication risk, as dilution 
potential is low during summer low-flows, while biological activity is high (Neal and Jarvie, 2005;  Jarvie 
et al., 2006). 
In many lowland areas in the UK, and the south of England in particular, there are growing pressures for 
increased housing in rural and agricultural ‘green belt’ areas (Evans et al., 2003).  Increased habitation 
density will lead to increased nutrient loading to rivers from increased STW requirements unless more 
stringent control on nutrient fluxes is introduced.  This increasing pressure will be exacerbated by reduced 
dilution resulting from increased abstraction of water from the river and groundwater sources.  Further, 
with increased global warming and predicted reduction in rainfall for the lowland UK (UKCIP, 2008), the 
problem of low flows and increased water usage requirements will compound the problem.

Study area 
General 
The data presented here cover the river catchment areas of Suffolk between Southwold in the north to the 
Alde-Ore estuary in the south (Figure 1).  The landscape is predominantly rural in character, largely used 
for arable farming.  Spatial land-use data (NRFA, 2008) show that predominant land use is arable and 
horticulture (74 to 76%, England average 34.1%), with grassland (12 to 15%, England average 38.1%), 
woodland (4.4 to 7%, England average 11.0%) and built-up areas (4 to 5%, England average 11.2%). 
The main rivers draining the area are the Blyth to the north, and the Alde-Ore system to the south, with 
recorded average annual rainfall (1961-1990) of around 600 mm (Blyth 591 mm; Alde 592 mm; Ore 
597mm).  General characteristics of the main river catchments are given in Table 1. 
The rivers considered here are small (mean flow 1961 to 2006 <0.5 m3s-1), flow from west to east, and are 
close to the coast, and so are recognised for their ecological significance:  for example the Easton Broad 
River (see Figure 1), is designated as a Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) for most of its length, and 
the lower reaches form part of the Benacre to Easton Bavents Lagoons, designated as a Special Area of 
Conservation (SAC) under the EU habitats directive (Howden et al., 2006).

Data Sources 
Water quality data were provided by the Environment Agency of England and Wales (EA) for 60 sample 
sites for the period between August 1981 and October 2005.  This included:  sets of major ion data for the 
River Blyth at Blyford, the River Alde at Langham and the River Ore at Beversham;  around 60 sites 
sampled on a minimum of 40 occasions over the period for the following determinands: alkalinity at pH 
4.5 (as CaCO3); ammonia (as N); chloride (as Cl); chlorophyll-a; nitrite (as N); TOxN; TRP or 
orthophosphate (as P); pH; dissolved reactive silica (as SiO2); suspended solids at 105°C; water 
temperature; and turbidity.  It is important to note that the data presented by the EA as SRP concentration 
is actually total reactive phosphorus, as the sample is unfiltered (Mainstone et al., 2000).   Conversions 
were used to express alkalinity at pH 4.5 as bicarbonate (HCO3), which was then also used to calculate 
the excess partial pressure of carbon dioxide (EpCO2) using the method outlined by Neal et al.(2000). The 
hydrometric data used came from the National River Flow Archive (NRFA) datasets 
(www.ceh.ac.uk/data/nrfa/index.html) for catchment stations (see Figure 1) ref. 35003 (River Alde at 
Farnham), 35004 (River Ore at Beversham) and 35013 (River Blyth at Holton), are also used to 
investigate relationships between concentrations and flow.

Methods 
The long-term monitoring data were summarised in a GIS-framework and used to support three sets of 
analyses, the salient points of which are presented here: 
1. Major ion concentrations, inter-determinand relationships and relationships with flow to support 
interpretation of catchment hydrological and hydrochemical functioning. 
2. Spatial distributions of nutrient concentrations over the region and relationships with biological 
indicators such as pH and EpCO2 
3. Where sufficient data were available, decomposition of nutrient concentration time series into diffuse- 
and point-source inputs, to provide an indication of the importance of different source-types and their 
relative contribution to N and P loading.

For items 1, and 2, the information is presented in the form of panel plots for determinands, summary 
tables and regional maps, while for item 3 the following methodology was used. 
The relationships between nutrient concentration and flow at each study site were assessed using the Load 
Apportionment Model (Bowes et al., 2008).  The model is based on the fundamental difference in the 
timing of point and diffuse nutrient inputs.  Point source inputs from sewage treatment works are 
relatively constant through the year, and will be unrelated to river flow.  Therefore, if a river received all 
of its nutrient input from STW effluent, the nutrient load would remain constant, and concentrations 
would decrease reciprocally with increasing river flow.  Diffuse sources are predominantly rainfall 
dependant, and therefore a river receiving only diffuse nutrient input would receive increasing nutrient 
load with increasing river flow.  The Load Apportionment Model quantifies these constant 
(approximating to point source) inputs and rain / flow-dependent (approximating to diffuse source) inputs 
using a simple power-law function, to parameterise empirical fits to paired flow and nutrient 
concentration observed at each study site.  The model also determines the flow, Qe, at which point and 
diffuse inputs to the river are equal, which is of great value when considering nutrient management 
options (Bowes et al., 2008).   
The Load Apportionment Model requires that the empirical data set of phosphorus and flow for each site 
covers the full river flow conditions observed at the site.  The data sets used in this study are based on 
monthly sampling interval, which can greatly under-represent high flow events and their related 
phosphorus exports (Jordan et al., 2005).  However, due to the long period of monthly monitoring used in 
this study, each data set consists of relatively large numbers of observations (River Blythe, n = 120; River 
Alde, n = 270; River Ore, n = 224) which will capture the full range of river flows.

Results 
General 
Water quality data from the period 1981 to 2005 are summarised in Table 3.  Major ion data (alkalinity, 
calcium, chloride, magnesium, potassium, sodium, and sulphate) are available at three sites:  the River 
Fromus at Gromford, the River Blyth at Blyford and the River Alde at Farnham (Table 2).  These data are 
plotted to show inter-ion relationships (Figure 2).  Examples of relationships between major ions and flow 
are shown for the River Alde in Figure 3. 
Water Quality

Alkalinity shows limited variability (164 to 295 mg CaCO3 l-1), with lower values corresponding to those 
areas where tidal influence is of importance (e.g. in the Ore/Alde Estuary, River Tang).  Chloride 
concentrations are higher for sampling sites close-to or below the tidal limit with extremely high 
concentrations in some places (i.e. >10,000 mg Cl l-1 on a regular basis).  
Regional long-term TRP / TOxN monitoring 
Concentrations of total oxidised nitrogen (TOxN) vary (Figure 4a): average concentration for the region 
is 7.85 mg N l-1, with a range in average of 0.59 to 15.07 mg N l-1.  Lowest average concentrations (0.59 
mg N l-1) are observed in the Dunwich River (which also tends to have high Cl - average 78 mg l-1), and 
the highest average concentrations are observed in the River Wang to the north (15.07 mg N l-1). 
For the purposes of water quality management within the Nitrates Directive, the maximum allowable 
concentration for drinking water is 11.3 mg N l-1, which would most likely be an assessment criterion for 
surface waters, excepting heavily modified water bodies.  With the exception of the Rivers Wang and 
Ore, where average TOxN concentrations already exceed this threshold (133 and 105% respectively) and 
the Dunwich River where concentrations are very low (5% of the threshold limit), the remainder are 
presently at between  29 and 91% of this limit, with the Lothingland Hundred River (91%), Easton Broad 
River (72%), Minsmere River (71%), River Alde (86%), River Fromus (77%) and Black Ditch (72%) all 
at more than 70% of the limit. 
The average TRP concentration across the region is 0.73 mg P l-1, with the range of averages for 
component rivers lying between 0.05 and 4.47 mg P l-1 (Figure 4b).  There remains some uncertainty as to 
what threshold will be set for environmental management purposes, but two emerging values are used as 
targets for annual averages.  For high alkalinity waters, such as those encountered in this study, values of 
0.120 and 0.05 mg P l-1 are suggested (WFD UK TAG, 2006):  the respective values classify the rivers in 
terms of ‘Good’ and ‘High’ ecological status.  With the exception of samples from the Ore/Alde Estuary 
and the River Tang (0.07 and 0.05 mg P l-1) which lie within the ‘Good’ ecological status range, all other

TRP relationships with flow show that the highest TRP concentrations occur at low flows, indicating a 
point source input at each site.  These point sources are of particular relevance, as they will tend to occur 
during the summer periods when biological activity/response is at a maximum (Neal et al., 2005; Jarvie et 
al., 2006).  The TRP concentrations are relatively high at high flows for the River Alde at Farnham and 
the River Ore at Beversham, and therefore the TRP load increases with increasing river discharge, 
indicating that there is a significant, rainfall-dependant input of phosphorus. TOxN relationships with 
flow at all three sites show a pattern typical of diffuse source dominance, with a positive gradient in the 
concentration / flow relationship at low to intermediate flows.  At higher flows the TOxN concentrations 
either remained constant (for the Rivers Alde and Ore) at high flows, but decreased for the River Blyth, 
indicating a possible depletion of TOxN within the catchment during major storm events.

The Load Apportionment modelled fits to the concentration / flow data are shown in Figure 6, and the 
load coefficient values are given in Table 4.  For the River Alde at Farnham, the model estimated that 
flow-dependent (approximating to diffuse source) inputs contributed 88.4 % of the total annual TRP load, 
indicating that agriculture was the predominant source of phosphorus to the river.  However, constant 
phosphorus inputs (approximating to point sources) are dominant at flows of up to 0.14 m3 s-1 (the 
calculated Qe value) which, according to the available flow records, equated to 59% of the sampling 
period.  Above this flow, diffuse sources become dominant with total load apportionment results 
suggesting 11.6 % contribution from point source inputs and the remaining 88.4 % coming from diffuse 
sources.  
For the River Ore at Beversham, results are presented for three discrete periods as they show contrasting 
patterns of behaviour. 
Period 1 (1983 to November 1992): constant (point source) inputs are dominant up to a volumetric flow 
rate of 0.37 m3 s-1, which accounts for around 91% of the flow record, with estimated total TRP load 
contributions of 41.4 % and 58.6 % for point and diffuse sources respectively. 
Period 2 (1993 to November 1996): The model was unable to produce a satisfactory solution, as the data 
set during this period did not include any high – flow data points, due to the large sampling interval.  This 
highlights the problems associated with the existing EA data sets, and shows that efforts should be made 
to sample UK rivers at a much higher temporal resolution in the future, so that true nutrient load estimates 
can be made and new methodologies such as the Load Apportionment Model can be applied to them. 
Period 3 (1997 to November 2003): constant TRP contributions are dominant at flows of up to 0.31 m3 s-
1, which accounts for around 72 % of the period of record, leading to estimated TRP load contributions of 
36.7% and 63.3% for constant (point) and flow dependent (diffuse) sources respectively. 
For the River Blyth at Holton, constant (point source) inputs are dominant at flows of up to 0.177 m3 s-1, 
which accounts for around 58% of the period of record, and leads to an estimated TRP load 
apportionment of 30.6% and 69.4% for point and diffuse sources respectively.

Discussion 
General water quality 
The waters are generally Ca-HCO3 bearing as a result of soil and bedrock weathering where calcite 
(CaCO3) is present, and they tend to be moderately alkaline and oversaturated with respect to CO2, which 
reflects dissolution of calcite by atmospheric/soil CO2 and a net excess of respiration over photosynthesis. 
Patterns of decreasing major ion concentrations with flow indicate a groundwater source that becomes 
diluted at intermediate and high flows – notably alkalinity, Mg and SO4 reflecting the Crag and 
Palaeogene aquifer sources contributing to baseflow in the River Blyth, and alkalinity, Cl, Mg, Na and 
SO4 reflecting the Chalk, Crag and Palaeogene water contribution to the River Alde. 
Strong linear inter-determinand correlations most likely indicate a lack of chemical reactivity, with net 
conservative mixing processes between high-flow and low-flow endmember concentrations (Jarvie et al., 
2000). 
TRP 
The River Ore at Beversham and the River Blythe at Holton have estimated diffuse TRP inputs of ca. 60 
and 70 % of the total load respectively (Table 4), indicating the dominance of agriculture as a source of P 
in these largely arable catchments with low human population density.  However, in terms of controlling 
eutrophication, it is the nutrient concentrations (rather than loads) during the plant and algae growing 
seasons that control nuisance epiphytic algal growth, and so are critical for catchment managers to 
consider (Hilton et al., 2006).  The maximum TRP concentrations observed in the River Blyth and River 
Ore occur at flows that are below the calculated Qe value (i.e the flow at which point and diffuse inputs 
are equal) (Figure 6), and so are mostly point source in origin.  Also, most of the data points observed 
during the algae and plant growing periods also occur at times of point source dominance.  This indicates 
that even in these predominantly rural catchments with low population density, it is clear that to reduce 
eutrophication risk and improve the ecology and water quality at these sites, most phosphorus mitigation 
efforts need to be targeted at sewage inputs.

The River Alde at Farnham receives an estimated 88.4% of its annual TRP load from diffuse sources.  
The majority of the highest TRP concentrations (around 400 µg l-1) occur at flows > Qe (Figure 6), but 
those occurring during the algae growing season occur in equal numbers at flows greater and less than Qe.  
This implies that catchment managers should target both sewage and agricultural inputs in this catchment. 
Nitrate 
The long-term average nitrogen concentration for the Suffolk rivers (7.85 mg/l) is similar to, and slightly 
lower than, that for other agriculturally-impacted eastern UK rivers such as the Great Ouse and Thames 
(average 8.4 and 8.2 mg N l-1 respectively, Neal and Robson, 2000) and for rivers in the Humber Basin 
(average 9.6 mg N l-1, Neal et al., 2008)). The importance of this agricultural component is well-
established and is illustrated for the eastern UK rivers by lower average NO3-N concentrations in the low 
intensity agricultural catchments of the north-eastern UK rivers and the low intensity agricultural and 
industrial Humber catchments (averages 1.9 and 5.9 mg N l-1 respectively) compared with the agricultural 
catchments of East Anglia (average 10.5 mg N l-1) (Robson and Neal, 2000; Neal et al., 2008b). 
There are consistent flow and seasonal patterns for TOxN with higher concentrations during the autumn 
and winter months occurring across all the Suffolk rivers, which most likely reflects a combination of two 
processes:  (1) within-river uptake during biologically-active periods of the spring and summer (Bowes et 
al., 2005b) and  (2) flushing of nitrogen from agricultural lands during the autumn and winter periods, 
which is largely related to the hydrobiogeochemical processing of N within the catchment, and the timing 
and nature of local farming practices. 
Nutrient status and biological water quality  
General Quality Assessment (GQA) data published by the EA ( available at www.environment-21 
agency.gov.uk) for biological status, N and P concentrations is shown in Figure 7.  For the period 1990 to 
2000, the percentage length of rivers attaining ‘very good’ biological status doubles, a change which also 
corresponds to a more than 50% reduction (40.1 to 13.7%) in river reaches classified as having ‘very 
high’ (> 1.0 mg P l-1) phosphorus concentrations.  Over the same period, there are increases in the 
percentages of river lengths with ‘high’ or ‘very high’ nitrate concentrations (30 to 40 or > 40 mg NO3 l-1

Conclusions 
The high concentrations of TRP and TOxN found in most of the Suffolk rivers considered here pose a 
clear challenge for water quality management. Within this context, there are a number of factors which 
will ultimately determine what management strategies may be required, and how they will be 
implemented. 
Although some successful source-decomposition has enabled a view of the relative contribution of point 
and diffuse TRP sources at different volumetric river flow rates to be made, the present monitoring data is 
not ideal to define the exact sources, but some conclusions are none-the less evident: 
(1) For TRP, point sources are dominant at low flows, with diffuse sources becoming 
dominant at intermediate to high flow; 
(2) For TOxN, diffuse sources are dominant irrespective of the flow conditions. 
In order to further improve understanding of the relative importance of TRP sources and links with flow 
conditions, monitoring should continue and be improved to cover a wider range of flow conditions 
throughout the seasonal cycle, either by introducing storm sampling or increasing the sampling frequency.  
Consideration should also be given to identifying the relative contributions of agricultural and population-
based TRP point sources.  Given such sources control streamwater-TRP during low flow periods, 
coinciding with periods of primary production, it is essential that attention be focussed on understanding 
the nature and extent of such sources, enabling development of appropriate strategies to mitigate and 
reduce their influence. 
For N, reduction in fertiliser applications will not necessarily translate into a rapid of proportional 
reduction in TOxN concentrations in the streams and rivers (e.g. Boorman, 2003) and there are complex 
within-catchment processes for both the nutrients and hydrology in relation to the soil, unsaturated and 
saturated zones (Smettem, 1986; Parker et al., 1991; Jackson et al., 2006). 
It is of crucial importance that long-term monitoring of such agriculturally-impacted river systems 
continues, particularly where that builds on existing data-rich monitoring sites.  However, given the
